questions.question: When turgor pressure equals osmotic pressure, water potential becomes:
questions.explanation: When turgor pressure equals the osmotic pressure (or solute potential with opposite sign), the water potential of the cell becomes zero. At this point, net water movement stops. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: The ascent of sap can occur up to a height of:
questions.explanation: In tall trees like redwoods, water can rise to heights of over 100 meters through the xylem, primarily due to transpiration pull. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Transpiration helps in:
questions.explanation: Transpiration helps in the absorption and upward movement of water and minerals from roots to leaves. It also cools leaf surfaces by evaporative cooling. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: The major route for transpiration is:
questions.explanation: Transpiration occurs mainly through the stomata in the leaves. Stomatal transpiration accounts for about 90% of water loss. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: A cell placed in hypotonic solution becomes:
questions.explanation: When a cell is placed in a hypotonic solution, water enters the cell and the cell becomes turgid. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: The water potential of pure water at standard temperature and pressure is:
questions.explanation: The water potential of pure water at standard temperature (273 K) and standard atmospheric pressure (1 atm) is taken to be zero. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT transported through xylem?
questions.explanation: Xylem primarily transports water and dissolved minerals. Organic food (like sucrose) is transported through phloem. However, some organic nitrogen compounds can be transported in xylem. (NCERT Page 187, 189)

questions.question: What happens at the sink during phloem transport?
questions.explanation: At the sink, sugar is unloaded from the phloem. This decreases the osmotic pressure at the sink and water moves out, maintaining the pressure flow. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: Imbibition pressure can be very high, for example:
options: Swelling of seeds can break flower pots
questions.explanation: The pressure that is produced by the swelling of wood has been used to split rocks. Imbibition pressure is so high that swelling seeds can even break flower pots. (NCERT Page 185)

questions.question: Apoplast movement is blocked at the endodermis by:
questions.explanation: The apoplastic movement of water is blocked at the endodermis by a band of suberised matrix called the Casparian strip. (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: Root pressure is developed due to:
options: Active absorption of minerals followed by osmotic entry of water
questions.explanation: Active absorption of minerals followed by the osmotic movement of water into the xylem of the root creates root pressure. (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: The inner wall of guard cells (facing the stoma) is:
questions.explanation: The inner wall of guard cells (towards the stomatal pore) is thicker than the outer wall. This differential thickening causes the guard cells to curve when turgid, opening the stoma. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: Imbibition is:
options: Absorption of water by hydrophilic substances
questions.explanation: Imbibition is a special type of diffusion when water is absorbed by solids – colloids – causing them to enormously increase in volume. (NCERT Page 185)

questions.question: The rate of diffusion is NOT affected by:
questions.explanation: The rate of diffusion is affected by concentration gradient, permeability of membrane separating them, temperature and pressure. Size of organ does not affect diffusion rate. (NCERT Page 181)

questions.question: The movement of molecules from a region of higher concentration to lower concentration is called:
questions.explanation: Diffusion is the movement of molecules from a region of higher concentration to a region of lower concentration. (NCERT Page 181)

questions.question: The cohesion-tension-transpiration pull model was proposed by:
questions.explanation: The cohesion-tension-transpiration pull theory of water transport was proposed by Dixon and Joly. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: When a plant cell is placed in hypertonic solution:
questions.explanation: If a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution, water leaves the cell and the cell shrinks. This shrinkage of protoplasm from the cell wall is called plasmolysis. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: Active transport is characterized by:
options: Movement against concentration gradient using ATP
questions.explanation: Active transport is the pumping of substances across membranes against a concentration gradient, i.e., uphill transport. It requires energy (ATP). (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: The movement of minerals in plants occurs through:
questions.explanation: Once minerals are absorbed by roots, they are transported upward along with water through the xylem. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: The water column in xylem does not break because of:
options: Cohesion between water molecules and adhesion to vessel walls
questions.explanation: The properties of cohesion (between water molecules) and adhesion (between water and vessel walls) prevent the water column from breaking even under high tension. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Which of the following is true about passive transport?
options: Is called diffusion when the transport is along the concentration gradient
questions.explanation: Transport along the concentration gradient, i.e., passive transport, includes diffusion. Passive transport does not require ATP. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: When two types of molecules move in the same direction across a membrane, it is called:
questions.explanation: When two types of molecules move across a membrane in the same direction, it is called symport. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Which of the following can be a source of food?
questions.explanation: Source is the part of plant where food is synthesized (leaves) or stored (storage organs when mobilizing food). Fruits, root tips, and developing seeds are sinks. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: Porins are proteins that form:
options: Large pores in outer membranes of plastids, mitochondria and bacteria
questions.explanation: Porins are proteins that form large pores in the outer membranes of plastids, mitochondria and some bacteria allowing molecules up to the size of small proteins to pass through. (NCERT Page 182)

questions.question: The water potential is denoted by the Greek symbol:
questions.explanation: Water potential is denoted by the Greek symbol Psi (Ψ). (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Guttation is:
options: Exudation of liquid water from leaves
questions.explanation: Guttation is the exudation of water in liquid form from the margins or tips of leaves, especially noticeable early in the morning. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: Cohesion refers to:
options: Attraction between water molecules and vessel walls
questions.explanation: Cohesion is the mutual attraction between water molecules due to hydrogen bonding. This property helps maintain the continuous water column in xylem. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Channel proteins that allow water to pass through are called:
questions.explanation: Aquaporins are channel proteins that allow water to pass through the membrane. They are water-specific channels. (NCERT Page 182)

questions.question: Transpiration is defined as:
options: Loss of water in vapor form from aerial parts of plant
questions.explanation: Transpiration is the evaporative loss of water by plants. It occurs mainly through the stomata in the leaves. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: Transpiration occurs at a faster rate in:
questions.explanation: Transpiration occurs at a faster rate during the day when stomata are open for gas exchange during photosynthesis. Temperature and light are also higher during the day. (NCERT Page 187-188)

questions.question: The role of the endodermis in roots is to:
options: Regulate the substances entering the xylem
questions.explanation: The endodermis with Casparian strip ensures that water and dissolved substances enter the xylem only through the cell protoplasm, allowing selective absorption. (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: Guard cells differ from other epidermal cells in having:
questions.explanation: Guard cells are unique among epidermal cells in having chloroplasts, which help in the opening and closing of stomata. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: When guard cells lose water and become flaccid:
questions.explanation: When guard cells lose water and become flaccid, the stomata close. This happens when K+ ions move out of guard cells. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: Plasmolysis is:
options: Shrinkage of protoplasm from the cell wall
questions.explanation: When a cell is placed in a hypertonic solution, water leaves the cell and the cell shrinks. This shrinkage of protoplasm from the cell wall is called plasmolysis. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: Solute potential is always:
questions.explanation: Solute potential (Ψs) is always negative. The more the solute molecules, the lower (more negative) is the solute potential. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: The first step in absorption of water by roots is:
questions.explanation: Imbibition is the first step in absorption of water by roots. (NCERT Page 185)

questions.question: The direction of translocation in phloem is:
questions.explanation: Unlike xylem transport which is unidirectional (upward), phloem transport is bidirectional - food can move both up and down depending on the location of source and sink. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: Root pressure is most effective in:
questions.explanation: Root pressure provides a modest push in the overall water transport in plants, but it is most effective in shorter, herbaceous plants. It cannot account for the movement of water to the top of tall trees. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: The main form in which food is translocated in phloem is:
questions.explanation: Sucrose is the main form in which organic food is translocated through the phloem. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: According to the cohesion-tension-transpiration pull theory, water rises in xylem due to:
options: Transpiration pull with cohesion and adhesion of water molecules
questions.explanation: According to the cohesion-tension theory, the pull from transpiration creates tension that pulls water up through xylem vessels. Water molecules stick together (cohesion) and to vessel walls (adhesion), forming a continuous column. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Potometer is used to measure:
questions.explanation: A potometer is an apparatus used to measure the rate of transpiration indirectly by measuring the rate of water uptake by a cut shoot. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Diffusion is a slow process and is not dependent on:
questions.explanation: Diffusion is a slow process and is not dependent on a living system. It is a passive process driven by the concentration gradient. (NCERT Page 181)

questions.question: Carrier proteins are highly selective because they:
questions.explanation: Carrier proteins or permeases are highly selective. They bind to specific molecules and undergo a change in shape to transport them across the membrane. (NCERT Page 182)

questions.question: The symplast pathway involves movement through:
questions.explanation: The symplastic pathway is the movement through the cytoplasm of cells connected by plasmodesmata (cytoplasmic bridges). (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: The pressure exerted by the protoplasm against the cell wall is called:
questions.explanation: When water enters a plant cell, the cell swells and the turgor pressure or pressure potential is developed due to pressure exerted by the protoplasm against the cell wall. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a means of transport in plants?
questions.explanation: Plants use diffusion, facilitated diffusion, and active transport for movement of substances. Unlike animals, plants do not have muscular contraction as they lack muscles. (NCERT Page 181)

questions.question: Facilitated diffusion requires:
questions.explanation: Facilitated diffusion is passive transport that requires special membrane proteins (porins, channel proteins, carrier proteins) but does not require ATP. (NCERT Page 182)

questions.question: Water can move through roots via:
questions.explanation: Water moves through the root either by apoplast (cell wall continuum) or symplast (cytoplasmic continuum through plasmodesmata). (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: Osmosis is:
options: Diffusion of water across a semipermeable membrane
Movement of solute from low to high concentration
Movement of water from low to high concentration
questions.explanation: Osmosis is the term used for the diffusion of water across a selectively permeable membrane. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: Companion cells are associated with:
questions.explanation: Sieve tube elements are associated with companion cells. Companion cells help in the loading and unloading of sugars into sieve tubes. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: The pressure flow or mass flow hypothesis for phloem transport was given by:
questions.explanation: The pressure flow or mass flow hypothesis was given by Ernst Munch to explain the translocation of food in phloem. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: The negative pressure or tension in xylem sap is created by:
questions.explanation: Transpiration creates negative pressure or tension in the xylem sap, which pulls water upward through the plant. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: The water potential equation is:
questions.explanation: The water potential equation is Ψw = Ψs + Ψp, where Ψw is water potential, Ψs is solute potential and Ψp is pressure potential. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: The apoplast pathway consists of:
questions.explanation: The apoplastic movement of water occurs through the network of cell walls and intercellular spaces. (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: The cytoplasmic bridges that connect adjacent plant cells are called:
questions.explanation: Plasmodesmata are cytoplasmic bridges that connect the cytoplasm of adjacent plant cells, allowing the symplastic movement of substances. (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: The magnitude of lowering of water potential due to dissolved solutes is called:
questions.explanation: The magnitude of lowering of water potential due to dissolution of a solute is called solute potential or osmotic potential (Ψs). (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Addition of solutes to water:
options: Has no effect on water potential
questions.explanation: If some solute is dissolved in pure water, the solution has fewer free water molecules and the concentration of water decreases, reducing its water potential. Hence, all solutions have lower water potential than pure water. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Root pressure can be demonstrated by:
options: Guttation and exudation from cut stem
questions.explanation: Root pressure can be demonstrated by observing guttation (exudation of water from leaf margins) and by exudation of sap from a freshly cut stump. (NCERT Page 186-187)

questions.question: Pressure potential (Ψp) is usually:
questions.explanation: Pressure potential is usually positive, though in the case of water moving in the xylem, it can be negative. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: Which cells are involved in loading sugars into phloem?
questions.explanation: Companion cells actively help in loading sugars into sieve tube elements using ATP. They have numerous mitochondria for this purpose. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: The sieve tube elements in phloem are connected by:
questions.explanation: Sieve tube elements are connected to each other by sieve plates, which have sieve pores allowing the flow of substances. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: Antiport is the transport mechanism where:
options: Two molecules move in same direction
Two molecules move in opposite directions
questions.explanation: When two types of molecules move in opposite directions across a membrane, it is called antiport. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Long distance transport of substances in plants occurs through:
questions.explanation: For long distance transport, plants have developed a vascular system consisting of xylem and phloem. This is also called translocation through mass flow or bulk flow. (NCERT Page 185)

questions.question: Phloem loading refers to:
options: Active transport of sugars into sieve tube elements
questions.explanation: Phloem loading is the process by which sugars produced in mesophyll cells are actively transported into the sieve tube elements of phloem. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: A solution that has more solute concentration than the cell sap is called:
questions.explanation: A solution is hypertonic (or hyperosmotic) if it has a greater concentration of solutes than the cell. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: Sieve tube elements are:
questions.explanation: Sieve tube elements are living cells but they lack nucleus at maturity. They depend on companion cells for their metabolic needs. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: During seed germination, the source of food is:
questions.explanation: During seed germination, storage organs (cotyledons or endosperm) become the source, providing food for the growing embryo. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: Translocation of food in plants occurs through:
questions.explanation: Transport of food, i.e., organic solutes from leaves to other parts of the plant body (translocation) occurs in the phloem. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: Minerals are absorbed by roots mainly by:
questions.explanation: Most minerals are absorbed by roots through active transport, which requires energy in the form of ATP. (NCERT Page 189)

questions.question: Which of the following factors does NOT affect the rate of transpiration?
questions.explanation: Factors affecting transpiration include temperature, light, humidity, wind speed, and number of stomata. Root pressure is not a major factor affecting transpiration rate. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Water moves from:
options: Low water potential to high water potential
Low solute concentration to high solute concentration
High water potential to low water potential
High osmotic pressure to low osmotic pressure
questions.explanation: Water moves from its region of higher chemical potential (higher water potential) to its region of lower chemical potential (lower water potential) until equilibrium is reached. (NCERT Page 184)

questions.question: According to the mass flow hypothesis, phloem sap moves due to:
options: Active transport along the sieve tubes
Pressure gradient created by loading of sugar at source and unloading at sink
questions.explanation: According to the mass flow hypothesis, sugars are actively loaded at the source creating high osmotic pressure, and unloaded at the sink. This creates a pressure gradient that drives mass flow. (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: The Casparian strip is made up of:
questions.explanation: The Casparian strip is a band of suberised (waxy) matrix present in the walls of endodermal cells that blocks the apoplast pathway. (NCERT Page 186)

questions.question: For a solution at atmospheric pressure, water potential equals:
questions.explanation: For a solution at atmospheric pressure (open beaker), water potential (Ψw) = solute potential (Ψs). (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Uniport refers to:
options: Transport of two molecules in same direction
Transport of two molecules in opposite directions
Transport of one type of molecule independent of others
questions.explanation: When a molecule moves across a membrane independent of other molecules, the process is called uniport. (NCERT Page 183)

questions.question: Mass flow or bulk flow is:
options: Movement of a substance en masse from one point to another due to pressure difference
questions.explanation: Mass flow is the movement of substances en masse from one point to another as a result of pressure differences between the two points. (NCERT Page 185)

questions.question: Tracheids and vessels are:
questions.explanation: Tracheids and vessel elements are dead cells at maturity. They lack protoplasm which allows unimpeded flow of water. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: High humidity:
questions.explanation: Higher humidity in the atmosphere reduces the rate of transpiration because the concentration gradient of water vapor between the leaf interior and the atmosphere is reduced. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Food is transported in phloem from:
questions.explanation: In phloem, food is transported from source (where food is produced or stored, like leaves) to sink (where food is used or stored, like roots, fruits). (NCERT Page 190)

questions.question: Which of the following shows imbibition?
options: Swelling of seeds when soaked in water
questions.explanation: Examples of imbibition include absorption of water by seeds and dry wood. When seeds are soaked in water, they swell due to imbibition. (NCERT Page 185)

questions.question: The main force responsible for the ascent of sap in tall trees is:
questions.explanation: Transpiration pull is the main driving force for the ascent of sap in tall trees. The pull is generated by the evaporation of water from mesophyll cells. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Adhesion refers to:
options: Attraction between water molecules and xylem vessel walls
questions.explanation: Adhesion is the attraction of water molecules to polar surfaces like the cellulose in the cell walls of tracheary elements. (NCERT Page 188)

questions.question: Which ion is required for stomatal opening?
questions.explanation: Potassium ions (K+) are essential for stomatal opening. K+ influx into guard cells increases their osmotic potential, causing water uptake and turgidity. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: Stomata open when guard cells become:
questions.explanation: When guard cells absorb water and become turgid, the stomata open due to the differential thickening of guard cell walls. (NCERT Page 187)

questions.question: Absorption of water by roots primarily occurs through:
questions.explanation: Water is absorbed along with mineral salts from the soil by the root hairs. (NCERT Page 186)
